title: Josh Hill enters golf’s record books as the youngest ever winner of a world ranking event but misses out on £10,000 prize money
text:
English 15-year-old Josh Hill watched £10,000 cruelly diverted from his bank account on Wednesday, but was still “ecstatic” to see his name enter golf’s record books after becoming the youngest male golfer to win an officially recognised professional tournament.

With a brilliant 62 for a 17-under total, the schoolboy fended off a field boasting seasoned European Tour pros to claim the Al Ain Open crown in Abu Dhabi. As an amateur, Hill was not allowed to accept the first prize, with countryman Harry Ellis benefiting instead for coming second, two shots behind.

However, what Hill earned could not be measured in monetary terms as he took the record off Ryo Ishikawa as the youngest champion at an event boasting Official World Ranking points. The Japanese golfer was almost two months older than Hill when prevailing on his home tour in 2007.

Danny Willett, the 2016 Masters champion, and Sir Nick Faldo were just two of the sport’s established figures to posted their congratulations on social media.

“I really don't know what to say right now. I am shocked and stunned," said Hill. "If you had told me during the summer that I will be winning a Mena Tour title against professionals and become the youngest ever winner of an Official World Golf Ranking event, I would have laughed.
